description: Inherited from Middle English [Term?], from Old French reboter, rebuter, rebouter, etc., from re- +‎ boter, buter, bouter (“to butt”). Entered English around 1302-1307.

verbs.description: rebut (third-person singular simple present rebuts, present participle rebutting, simple past and past participle rebutted)

entries.meaning: To drive back or beat back; to repulse.
To deny the truth of something, especially by presenting arguments that disprove it.
